fundamental_1.title:
Given:  
  
`console.log(myNum);`  
  
`var myNum;`  
  
`myNum = 5`   
  
 what value is logged?

labels.title: A reference error is thrown because variable is used before it's been declared.
`undefined` because in js declarations are hoisted.
None of the above.
A reference error is thrown because the variable is used without being declared. JS hoists declarations only.
`undefined` because in js initializations and declarations are hoisted.
None of the above.

fundamental_3.title:
Given:  
  
`console.log(myNum);`  
  
`if(1) {`  
 `let myNum = 5`  
  
 `}`  
  
  what value is logged?

labels.title: `Uncaught ReferenceError` because let is block scoped and so not hoisted outside the conditional.
`undefined` because in js initializations and declarations are hoisted.

fundamental_4.title: Which of the following are exclusively primitive *data types*?

labels.title: `number`, `bigint`, `boolean`, `undefined`, `null`
`string`, `number`, `bigint`, `boolean`, `undefined`, `symbol`
`Object`, `Array`, `Map`, `Set`, `Function`, `Date`
`Object`, `Array`, `Map`, `Set`, `boolean`, `undefined`

fundamental_5.title: What is the difference between `string` and `String`, `boolean` and `Boolean`, `symbol` and `Symbol` etc. ?

labels.title: The lowercase version is a primitive data type with no methods while the uppercase version is a wrapper object with methods.
There is no difference. Both can be used interchangeably.
The lowercase version is the value assigned by the uppercase version.
None of the above.

fundamental_6.title:
Given `let a = true;` and `let b = new Boolean(true);`  
  
What will `typeof a` and `typeof b` return?

labels.title: Both will return the string `boolean` since both pass in a boolean argument.
Both will return the string `object`
`boolean` and `object` respectively because the first is a primative value and the second is an instance of the Boolean constructor.
`object` and `boolean` respectively because `new Boolean()` always returns a primitive value.
